prior_works.title: The Earth Mover’s Distance as a Metric for Image Retrieval
prior_works.authors: Y. Rubner, C. Tomasi, L. J. Guibas
prior_works.role: Foundational optimal transport metric for comparing distributions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the practical formulation of Wasserstein/EMD for comparing histograms and images, providing the core metricic foundation that the spherical convolutional Wasserstein distance builds upon to compare climate fields as distributions.

prior_works.title: Sinkhorn Distances: Lightspeed Computation of Optimal Transport
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Entropic regularization and Sinkhorn iterations made OT tractable at scale; the proposed spherical convolutional Wasserstein distance relies on such efficient OT solvers to compute many local distributional comparisons over the sphere.

prior_works.title: Sliced and Radon Wasserstein Barycenters of Measures
prior_works.authors: Nicolas Bonneel, Julien Rabin, Gabriel Peyré, Hanspeter Pfister
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the idea of using 1D projections (sliced/Radon) to approximate Wasserstein distances; the new method generalizes this projection principle by replacing linear projections with localized spherical convolutional projections to capture spatial variability.

prior_works.title: Sliced Wasserstein Generative Models
prior_works.authors: Ishan Deshpande, Ziyu Zhang, Alexander G. Schwing
prior_works.role: Combining convolutional features with Wasserstein-type discrepancies
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that Wasserstein distances computed on projected/feature representations (often derived from convolutions) can drive powerful comparisons; this directly motivates using convolutional projections to define a Wasserstein-based similarity for spatial climate data.

prior_works.title: Learning SO(3)-Equivariant Representations with Spherical CNNs
prior_works.authors: Carlos Esteves, Christine Allen-Blanchette, Ameesh Makadia, Kostas Daniilidis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the formalism for convolution on the sphere with rotation equivariance; the spherical convolutional projections in the proposed distance are grounded in these operators to respect the geometry of global climate fields.

prior_works.title: Computing Fourier transforms and convolutions on the 2-sphere
prior_works.authors: J. R. Driscoll, D. M. Healy Jr.
prior_works.role: Mathematical and computational basis for spherical convolution
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the harmonic-analysis framework enabling efficient, well-defined convolutions on S2; the paper’s spherical convolutional projections inherit this foundation to build geometrically faithful features for OT.

prior_works.title: Computational Optimal Transport: With Applications to Data Science
prior_works.role: Comprehensive theory and algorithms for OT (including on manifolds)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Synthesizes theory and scalable algorithms for Wasserstein distances and related variants; the proposed method’s design and implementation choices (regularization, discretization, and comparisons on geometric domains) align with this framework.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—defining a spherical convolutional Wasserstein distance for validating global climate models—sits at the intersection of optimal transport and spherical signal processing. Rubner, Tomasi, and Guibas (2000) established the Earth Mover’s Distance as a practical metric to compare distributions, which is the conceptual bedrock for quantifying discrepancies between climate fields. Cuturi’s (2013) Sinkhorn distances enabled scalable computation of OT, a prerequisite for repeatedly evaluating local distributional differences across the globe. To further improve efficiency and robustness, the approach draws from projection-based OT: Bonneel et al. (2015) introduced sliced/Radon Wasserstein distances via 1D projections, and Deshpande et al. (2018) showed that Wasserstein-type discrepancies computed on convolutional features can be highly effective, motivating the use of learned or fixed filters as projections rather than purely linear ones.

Because the data live on the sphere, the method must respect spherical geometry. Esteves et al. (2018) provide an SO(3)-equivariant framework for spherical convolutions, ensuring rotationally consistent features, while Driscoll and Healy (1994) supply the harmonic-analysis foundation for efficient and mathematically sound spherical convolutions. Finally, Peyré and Cuturi’s (2019) monograph consolidates the theoretical and algorithmic landscape of OT—including regularization and computation on geometric domains—guiding practical choices in the proposed metric. Together, these works directly inform the design of a geometry-aware, convolutionally projected Wasserstein distance tailored to evaluating CMIP climate model outputs against reanalysis data.
